question: Question_05
statement:
Let \emph{X} be a random variable with probability density function:

\[f(x) = \begin{cases} kx(1-x^4) & \text{ if } 0 \leq x \leq 1,\\ 0 & \text{ if } x < 0 \text{ or } x > 1. \end{cases}\]

(a) Find the value of \emph{k}.

(b) Find the mean $\mu$.

(c) Find an algebraic equation satisfied by the median \emph{m}.
sols:
\textbf{(a)} Using hint 1 we see that \emph{k} needs to be a positive
constant. We can calculate \emph{k} directly by integrating:

\begin{align*}
\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^1 kx(1-x^4)\,dx + \int_1^\infty 0\,dx \\
&= k \int_0^1 (x-x^5)\,dx \\
&= k\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2-\frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= k \left(\frac12 - \frac16\right) \\
&= \frac{k}3.
\end{align*}

The only way that this integral has value 1 is when \textbf{\emph{k} =
3}.

\textbf{(b)} Using the second hint and the fact that \emph{k} = 3 the
calculation is straight forward

\begin{align*}
\mu &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^1 (x)3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\
&= 3Â \int_0^1 (x^2-x^6)\,dx \\
&= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^3}3 - \frac{x^7}7\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= 3\left(\frac13 - \frac17\right) \\
&= \frac47.
\end{align*}

\textbf{(c)} Following the third hint we need to find that value
\emph{m} which satisfies

\[\int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx.\]

Since $\int_{-\infty}^0 f(x)\,dx = 0 = \int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx$ it is
clear that \emph{m} needs to be a number between 0 and 1. Therefore the
algebraic equation that \emph{m} satisfies is the following;

\begin{align*}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^m 3x(1-x^4)\,dx \\
&= 3\left.\left(\frac{x^2}2 - \frac{x^6}6\right)\right|_0^m \\
&= 3\left(\frac{m^2}2 - \frac{m^6}6\right).
\end{align*}
hints:
For $f$ to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two
conditions:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f$(x) $\geq$ 0 for all \emph{x},
\item
  $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1.$
\end{itemize}

Choose \emph{k} such that both conditions are fulfilled.

The formula for the mean $\mu$ is given by

\[\displaystyle \mu = \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx.\]

The median \emph{m} is that number which satisfies

\[\int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx.\]
